admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            satisfactory. The project objectives were mostly met, and,
            substantial strengthening capacity was achieved in key areas
            of the Environmental Impact Management Agency (BAPEDAL).
            However, a certain lack of initiative, and responsibility,
            may prevent the Agency from improving its ability to control
            pollution, and, effectively manage environmental
            adversities. The key lessons learned suggest, primarily,
            that the establishment of the Project Management Office
            (PMO) during preparation, with a continued role through
            implementation, was vital for success. Mainly, and because,
            it was managed by BAPEDAL, the office thus became the link
            among not only the Bank, and the consultants, but most
            importantly, the various potential donors. This contributed,
            not only to strengthen a new agency's capacity, but to
            actually resolve difficult issues which arose during
            implementation. However, a flexible balance in the provision
            of technical assistance (TA), would have been beneficial,
            since most of the TA was delivered upon completion, not in
            an advisory role. Thus, to complement technical components,
            ideally, counterpart managers per TA team should be
            assigned, and project design should include mechanisms for
            TA delivery. This could have fostered that sense of
            ownership, and, responsibility, needed for enhancing
            institutional capacity.
